quotes.quote: Arjuna retrieves a Brahmin's stolen wealth from thieves by scattering them with arrows, then returns it to the priest.
quotes.image_prompt: Ghibli Art: A golden bow rests against a tree at dusk, its string still vibrating. A single arrow lies on the grass nearby.
quotes.context: The text describes how Arjuna 'scattered the thieves with arrows and recovered that wealth' (Line 23639) after tracking them down. He then 'brought glory to the Brahmin' (Line 23641) by returning the stolen property. This occurs during Arjuna's travels before his forest exile, showing his commitment to protecting priestly property.

quotes.quote: The Naga princess Ulupi pulls Arjuna underwater into her father's palace, where he performs fire rituals that please the deity Agni.
quotes.image_prompt: Ghibli Art: A single blue-scaled hand emerges from still water, reflecting flickering firelight. The surface shimmers with golden ripples.
quotes.context: Lines 23722-23729 describe how 'the mighty-armed one was pulled down by the daughter of the Naga king' into an underwater palace. There Arjuna sees 'the fire well-arranged' and performs rituals where 'the fire was pleased with his fearless offerings.' This occurs during his pilgrimage at Gangadvara.

quotes.quote: Five celestial nymphs cursed to become crocodiles are freed when Arjuna pulls one from the water, breaking their century-long punishment.
quotes.image_prompt: Ghibli Art: A translucent apsarā floats above river reeds, her pearl necklace dissolving into mist. The last crocodile scale falls like a leaf.
quotes.context: Lines 23926-24051 detail how Arjuna encounters cursed apsarās who explain they were transformed by a sage's anger. When he pulls one crocodile from sacred waters (Line 23930), she reverts to her divine form. The text specifies this occurred at five pilgrimage sites avoided by ascetics due to the cursed nymphs.

quotes.quote: Citravahana, king of Manipura, explains his lineage produces only one heir per generation - either son or daughter - due to an ancient boon from Shiva.
quotes.image_prompt: Ghibli Art: A single lotus blooms in a stone fountain, its reflection perfectly mirrored in still water. No other flowers are visible.
quotes.context: Lines 23862-23872 describe King Citravahana telling Arjuna how his ancestor Prabhankara received Shiva's blessing for 'one offspring in each generation.' His daughter Citrangada thus carries the lineage, as 'she will surely continue our lineage.' This occurs when Arjuna visits coastal Manipura during his travels.

quotes.quote: The sage Dadhīca voluntarily relinquished his body so his bones could be used to create a divine thunderbolt for the gods to defeat their enemies.
quotes.image_prompt: Ghibli Art: A serene sage sits cross-legged in golden light, his translucent form dissolving into the air as white bones remain. Soft mist surrounds.
quotes.context: The text describes how Dadhīca, whose radiance equaled the sun, told the gods: 'I shall do what is beneficial for you today, O gods; I shall also relinquish my own body.' After his death, the gods took his bones as instructed to create the thunderbolt (vajra). This occurs when the gods approach Dadhīca's hermitage, which resembled heaven, seeking help against their enemies (Lines 46740-46753).

quotes.quote: The demon Vṛtra's roar caused the earth, sky, directions, and mountains to tremble when he confronted Indra in battle.
quotes.image_prompt: Ghibli Art: A colossal serpentine shadow coils against a stormy sky, its open maw sending visible sound waves that distort the landscape below. Pale moonlight.
quotes.context: The text states: 'By his bellowing, the earth, directions, sky, heaven, and mountains—everything trembled' when Vṛtra roared against Indra (Line 46806). This occurs during the battle where Vṛtra, protected by the Kālakeya demons, stands covering heaven and earth, causing even Indra to faint from fear (Lines 46772-46812).

quotes.quote: King Sagara's 60,000 sons were reduced to ashes by Kapila's gaze after they disturbed his meditation while searching for a sacrificial horse.
quotes.image_prompt: Ghibli Art: A golden-eyed sage sits motionless amidst swirling ashes that form spectral figures. A single white horse watches from a distance.
quotes.context: The text describes how the sons of Sagara, while digging into the earth to find a lost sacrificial horse, encountered Kapila: 'Opening his eyes wide... he burned to ashes those dull-witted sons of Sagara' (Lines 47316-47319). This occurs after they disregard Kapila's presence while violently searching the netherworld (Lines 47301-47319).

quotes.quote: The river Gaṅgā agreed to descend from heaven to purify the ashes of Sagara's sons, but required Lord Shiva to bear her force.
quotes.image_prompt: Ghibli Art: A translucent blue river goddess floats above mountain peaks, her cascading hair merging with waterfalls. A single trident leans against rocks.
quotes.context: Gaṅgā tells Bhagīratha: 'My force... is unbearable. No one in the three worlds is capable of bearing it... except for... the blue-throated Maheśvara' (Lines 47541-47545). This occurs after Bhagīratha's thousand-year austerity to bring Gaṅgā down for his ancestors' salvation (Lines 47473-47545).
